author: sky.cactus
content: Can you help me understand what caused you to think that 1559 would be changing the gas costs for access lists?

author: jochembrouwer
content: There is no reason for it to change, but the EIP does not mention what specific implementation of access lists it uses, so it is not self-contained (that it should use EIP2930 for access lists). IMO, EIPs should be self-contained: they should not leave any room for doubt.

author: jochembrouwer
content: How would I be able to figure out what access lists are if I was not aware of EIP2930?

author: sky.cactus
content: EIPs generally are changesets, and since gas costs for access lists (and everything else) aren't changing, they aren't mentioned.

author: sky.cactus
content: What I'm curious about is why you think we should specify that and not any of the other things that 1559 doesn't change?  What makes access lists special?

author: jochembrouwer
content: Look, I think that if you give me an EIP (like this one), I should be able to implement that EIP from the spec of that EIP (including references). I am able to figure out how to encode the transaction (2718), but it is not clear what these access lists are. They are probably 2930, but I am not sure. The EIPs should be self contained, IMO.

author: jochembrouwer
content: The main problem is that if these EIPs are not self-contained, theyre is room for interpretation, which is something which you do not want. If every client implements their own EIP with their own assumptions, then at the point we start running consensus tests we see that one client has implemented the EIP with different assumptions when compared to another client, which is not what you want.

author: sky.cactus
content: As as extreme example 1559 also doesn't tell you how to do a keccak256 hash, or a secp256k1 signature, or how to build a merkle trie, etc.  I'm trying to understand where you draw the line for listing what *doesn't* change?

author: jochembrouwer
content: I get your point, but what if there are two EIPs which implement access lists in a different way. How am I supposed to know what EIP I should use for the access lists?

author: sky.cactus
content: There literally are two ways to do a "sha3" hash.  üòÑ One is the Ethereum way and one is the rest-of-the-world way.  üòÅ

author: sky.cactus
content: The default assumption should always be, "don't change it if the spec doesn't say to change it" IMO.

author: jochembrouwer
content: In general: I actually think it would be much better to also keep references to whatever a keccak256 or a secp256k1 means. It is basic terminology within our ecosystem, but it would be much better (IMO) to also just reference whatever this is within the EIP. Like this you can cross-reference whatever it meant and therefore figure out whatever spec was meant

author: sky.cactus
content: Since access lists in Ethereum are handled one way prior to 1559, we should assume that isn't changing unless the spec says it is changing.

author: jochembrouwer
content: RE: keccak and sha3: I think this is different from access lists. In access lists this is a new thing. If there were 2 competing access lists then I would not be able to figure out what spec it meant: for sha3/keccak it is generally accepted whatever these are. Although I would still prefer (for completeness) to give full references to whatever is meant.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem here is that EIPs would end up being incredibly massive, which makes it harder for people to digest.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Why? You can just provide references as in a scientific paper

author: jochembrouwer
content: I generally think it would be much better to keep EIPs self-contained: if they are not, they leave room for interpretation, which in the end results to more consensus bugs than if this were not the case.

author: jochembrouwer
content: I am currently implementing this EIP and I will not be convinced I am correct until we have general consensus tests in ethereum/tests. The problem is that some parts of the EIP (like access lists) leave room to interpretation or some assumptions, which is not what you want. Based upon the EIP, I want to be reasonably sure I am correct in what I am programming, and that is not the case currently.

author: sky.cactus
content: That all being said, I have been pushing gently on changing to a living Ethereum spec for a bit now.  Have one canonical spec for Ethereum, and"EIPs" would be pull requests against that spec.

author: jochembrouwer
content: I agree here. There is no spec. If you would give me the yellow paper, I would probably build something which works different than what Ethereum is today - and I do not think that this is what you want.

author: jochembrouwer
content: In general it would be okay, but there are many gray parts which are not documented properly in the yellow paper, which eventually would lead to faulty clients being implemented, since you cannot assume that the client "guesses right" on those gray areas. I still find it weird that after reading the yellow paper multiple times, I still learn new things about the protocol which are not documented in the paper (how did clients end up to this consensus in the first place?)

author: lightclient
content: fwiw, i think it is very reasonable to clearly specify the intrinsic cost of a new transaction type - even if it uses the same constructs that had existed prior

author: lightclient
content: at minimum, it should point to 2930's spec of the access lists

author: sky.cactus
content: Being explicit about gas costs for new transaction types I think I can get on board with.

author: sky.cactus
content: Not just the access list part but the gas costs for the whole transaction.  Same as we do for all new opcodes and precompiles, we include gas costing as part of the specification.

author: lightclient
content: Yes, agree on being explicit about all gas costs related to the tx

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone should create a pull request against 1559.  üòÑ
